content_html:
How Understanding These Two Concepts of Time Can Change the Way you Live in the Present Forever

Michal Bernolak
Apr 2
“The easiest way to increase happiness is to control your use of time. Can you find more time to do the things you enjoy doing?” — Daniel Kahneman

Viewing time through a “fast” lens and a “slow” lens is a superpower that not many people can or want to acquire. We are all yearning for a sense of purpose in our day to day lives. Thoughts we have about what our time means to us, and how it should be spent, are likely carefully influenced by materialism — a nasty and unfortunate by-product of capitalism.

Defining fast and slow thinking

In Daniel Kahneman’s book, Thinking, Fast and Slow, he writes in detail about the concept of fast and slow thinking. He explains how our reactions to reality are controlled by two systems in our brain. Here is a brief definition:

System 1 is an automatic, fast and often unconscious way of thinking. It is autonomous and efficient, requiring little energy or attention, but is prone to biases and systematic errors.

An example of system 1 thinking is how your brain sees this equation:

3+3=?

Your brain immediately knows the answer and gives it to you without asking for your consent. System 1 is responsible for automatic processes, such as driving a car around a corner. You don’t have to think about it, you just do it.

System 2 is an effortful, slow and controlled way of thinking. It requires energy and can’t work without attention but, once engaged, it has the ability to filter the instincts of System 1.

An example of system 2 thinking is how your brain sees this equation:

19 x 28=?

You don’t have the answer immediately. You must think and draw from prior knowledge in a longer more thoughtful process. Although your system 1 brain immediately tells you that this is a problem to be solved, it’s increase in difficulty overwhelms system 1 and forces you to activate system 2. System 2 is activated in order to help you think more carefully, to think something through- slow deliberate thinking.

You cannot live without both

Humans are wired with system 1 and system 2 thinking because we absolutely need these two systems to survive. We need the immediate reaction abilities of system 1 to avoid a car accident. System 2 gives us the ability to carefully consider all the variables when deciding whether or not we should undergo a major surgery.

When we drink alcohol, we can suppress our System 2 thinking. We might find ourselves standing on the bar at 2 am, happily belting out Bohemian Rhapsody.

This happens because system 1 controls our immediate reaction to seize the opportunity to enjoy oneself. With system 2 beaten up and tied down by four shots of tequila, we lose the ability to think more deliberately about the embarrassment that will come later.

It is also system 2 thinking that later reminds us of our past performance and makes us think twice about having a 5th glass of wine. Without it, we would be subject to incredibly impulsive and possibly life threatening decisions, with no way to learn from the past and reflect on our experiences.

Re-defining how we look at the present and the future

Let’s look at the present and the immediate future like system 1 thinking. We will label the present, right now or today, as time system 1. Much like system 1 thinking, how we behave in time system 1 is fairly impulsive. We are reacting to the events happening to us in the present, or in anticipation of the immediate future, making game time decisions on the fly. We are always working in time system 1 because it is the present. Just by existing in this very moment, we are living in time system 1.

Where system 2 thinking is slow, calculated, and deliberate, time system 2 will be a similar idea. Time system 2 can be looked at as your goals, ambitions, and plans for the future (calculated, deliberate). This time should be pre-organized, and thought out by yourself, as a trajectory for your time system 1 to follow, long term. Like system 2 thinking, time system 2 activates when time system 1 becomes overwhelmed, or needs to course correct.

For example, in our world of time system 1 (the present), we might suddenly be presented with the option to participate in an activity such as playing a video game for a few hours. Your immediate reaction might be to play the game, because its fun and impulsive. If we have a time system 2 already in place, we know that this does not forward our goals and plans for the future, enabling us to course correct and do something more productive with that time.

The problem with time system 2

Unlike system 2 thinking, time system 2 is not hardwired into our brains. We don’t have to deliberately and carefully plan for the future if we don’t want to. We don’t need to have a goal, an ambition, an aim. It is completely up to us to put it in place.

Here’s the thing. With system 2 thinking, we have no choice, we have to have it (thankfully). We can choose not to use it, but it will always be there, helping us make better decisions about anything and everything. Without it, you might not think twice about driving down the highway in a blizzard, perhaps endangering your life.

We can agree that our success and even our survival depends on system 2 thinking. We absolutely need it. I think we can say the same for time system 2, but unfortunately its not required, and some of us choose not to have it, or are not aware of it’s importance.

Materialism is more prevalent than ever in society. It is the perfect distraction from creating a time system 2 that can guide your daily actions. We are constantly being trained to focus on buying and owning as many things as possible, looking a certain way, or behaving in a certain manner to fit in. In the absence of a time system 2, many of us end up addicted to our devices, in a continuous loop of unguided time system 1 behavior, living day to day with no real purpose, getting drunk every weekend.

We are expertly trained to seek instant gratification, to own the newest device or the coolest car. A time system 2 that takes effort and self restraint to develop is hard to find among many.

So how does all of this apply to me?

We need to ask ourselves if we have a clear time system 2 established. What are our goals? what are our ambitions? What do we want in life? If we are struggling to find an answer, or at least one that we are honestly deeply satisfied with, we need to cultivate a passion first.

You actually have to take time and sit down, to think, and make a plan. It takes a few good hours at least.

There are plenty of time system 2 templates out there. For example, society hands us one the minute we are born. School, house, family, retire. That is a basic fill in the blanks journey. It leaves lots of room for interpretation and error. It’s a good start, but it needs lots of seasoning.

Without creating a well rounded and filled out plan as our time system 2, we might find ourselves at the mercy of our impulsive reactions to the things that happen in time system 1. We might find ourselves fed up with staying up until 3 am watching youtube videos or constantly spending our money on eating out. At this point, unhappiness tends to creep in for a lot of people.

Create the map that leads to the treasure

Many of us are struggling to make sense of life, looking for a greater purpose. The reason for writing this article is to offer a different perspective on the importance of cultivating interests and passions and distilling goals from those things. We are capable of so much, and its not too late to start living by 2 systems of time instead of just one.

Think about how our day to day decisions can be better honed and guided by a bigger plan we can create for ourselves. Our creation of a time system 2 is the map that leads to the treasure, without it, we would be wandering aimlessly and digging a lot of pointless shallow holes. Take the time to make your time system 2 equally as relevant and important to your survival as system 2 thinking.
title: How Understanding These Two Concepts of Time Can Change the Way you Live in the Present Forever

Let’s look at the present and the immediate future like system 1 thinking. We will label the present, right now or today, as time system 1. For example, in our world of time system 1 (the present), we might suddenly be presented with the option to participate in an activity such as playing a video game for a few hours. Your immediate reaction might be to play the game, because its fun and impulsive. If we have a time system 2 already in place, we know that this does not forward our goals and plans for the future, enabling us to course correct and do something more productive with that time.

We can choose not to use it, but it will always be there, helping us make better decisions about anything and everything. Materialism is more prevalent than ever in society. It is the perfect distraction from creating a time system 2 that can guide your daily actions. In the absence of a time system 2, many of us end up addicted to our devices, in a continuous loop of unguided time system 1 behavior, living day to day with no real purpose, getting drunk every weekend.

We are expertly trained to seek instant gratification, to own the newest device or the coolest car. A time system 2 that takes effort and self restraint to develop is hard to find among many.

So how does all of this apply to me?

We need to ask ourselves if we have a clear time system 2 established. What are our goals? what are our ambitions? What do we want in life? If we are struggling to find an answer, or at least one that we are honestly deeply satisfied with, we need to cultivate a passion first.

You actually have to take time and sit down, to think, and make a plan. It takes a few good hours at least.

There are plenty of time system 2 templates out there. For example, society hands us one the minute we are born. School, house, family, retire. That is a basic fill in the blanks journey. It leaves lots of room for interpretation and error. It’s a good start, but it needs lots of seasoning.

Without creating a well rounded and filled out plan as our time system 2, we might find ourselves at the mercy of our impulsive reactions to the things that happen in time system 1. We might find ourselves fed up with staying up until 3 am watching youtube videos or constantly spending our money on eating out. At this point, unhappiness tends to creep in for a lot of people.

Many of us are struggling to make sense of life, looking for a greater purpose. The reason for writing this article is to offer a different perspective on the importance of cultivating interests and passions and distilling goals from those things. We are capable of so much, and its not too late to start living by 2 systems of time instead of just one.

Think about how our day to day decisions can be better honed and guided by a bigger plan we can create for ourselves. Our creation of a time system 2 is the map that leads to the treasure, without it, we would be wandering aimlessly and digging a lot of pointless shallow holes. Take the time to make your time system 2 equally as relevant and important to your survival as system 2 thinking.
